div.head: Letter From Charles Flowerree (Director of Systematic Review) to Stephen Gomersall (First Secretary of the British Embassy)
div.p: Last year you very kindly undertook to obtain your Government’s views on a collection of documents pertaining to the Buraimi dispute of 1953-1955. Now we are working on another series of documents dealing with the Iranian crisis of 1951 to 1954. Because of the intimacy of US-UK liaison in this affair and because of the possible sensitivity of some aspects of it from the British point of view, we would like to have the UK reaction before proceeding to publication. Therefore, we would like to follow the same procedure as was followed in the case of Buraimi.

The attached collection of 139 documents includes a number of British documents or extracts from them. Other report US-UK conversations or deal with subjects of interest to the UK. In a number of cases certain paragraphs or clauses have been bracketed and marked for excision. This means that from our point of view the document would be releasable after the indicated excisions have been made. In a very few cases, a document is marked “Deny”. This means that the document will not be published and it is included in this collection only for your information and as a means of suggesting the margins of our criteria. One document, not included, is a British memorandum of September 2, 1953, entitled “Persia, Review of the Recent Crisis.” This document you have already indicated to me is releasable with indicated excisions.

The documents are serially numbered in the upper left hand corner on the first page of each one. I have enclosed a list of documents by number. I would appreciate it if you would obtain the views of your Government regarding any parts of these documents which it considers sensitive. If you require any further clarification please let me know.
